00001 /********************************************************************************************************
00002 
00003 Copyright (C) 2008 Deepak Chandran
00004 contact: dchandran1@gmail.com
00005 
00006         This file contains an algorithm for finding loops in an adjacency matrix. 
00007         The edges can be negative or positive, such as in a Jacobian matrix. 
00008         
00009         The final output will list negative and positive loops. A negative loop is where the total
00010         product of all the edges in the loop is negative. Positive loop is a loop that is not negative.
00011         
00012         Originally, this code was used to find loops in the Jacobian matrix of an ODE. Loops
00013         in the Jacobian can indicate locations of positive feedback or negative feedback. However, 
00014         the code is genetic for any square matrix. 
00015         
00016         
00017 *********************************************************************************************************/
00018 #ifndef FIND_LOOPS_IN_SQUARE_ADJ_MATRIX
00019 #define FIND_LOOPS_IN_SQUARE_ADJ_MATRIX
00020 
00021 #include <stdlib.h>
00022 #include <stdio.h>
00023 #include <math.h>
00024 
00029 typedef struct
00030 {
00031         int numLoops;   //number of loops
00032         int numNodes;   //number of nodes in total
00033         int * loopLengths; //number of nodes in each loop
00034         int * loopTypes;        //type of each loop. -1 = negative, +1 = positive
00035         int * loopHomogeneous;  //type of each loop. 0 = mix of + and -, +1 = all same (eithe - or +)
00036         int ** nodes;   //array of nodes (index) in each loop. use numLoops and loopsLengths[i] to iterate
00037 } 
00038 LoopsInformation;
00039 
00044 #ifndef getValue
00045 
00046 #define getValue(array, N, i, j) ( array[ (((i)*(N)) + (j)) ] )
00047 
00048 #endif
